displayed_text: Patient: I get it. Doctor: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care. Family Member: Right. Doctor: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it. Patient: I’m with you. Doctor: Because you know it was nasty when we started. Family Member: I know. Doctor: And we had to-. Patient: Well, how can I get rid of it completely, though? Doctor: Well, we’re going to find out to see if it’s waking up. You’ve had everything under the sun thus far. Family Member: Right. Doctor: We will continue to be as aggressive. If there is something new, we’re probably going to take a sample of that. Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: but sometimes he gets snacks he shouldn’t have. Doctor: Yep. Family Member: But there’s not Metformin so we don’t have anything to combat all these sweets. So we need Doctor: Was he not taking Metformin at all? Family Member: No he’s got – they told him – and they reminded him today because of the alteration in his kidney function, Doctor: Oh okay because of that. Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Family Member: She was like… Doctor: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork

Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay? Doctor: It’s okay. Patient: I happy with it. Doctor: Great. You guys had a lot of good questions today. Patient: We learned to ask. You got to speak up. That’s right. Doctor: You got to advocate for yourself. Right? That’s absolutely the one thing. So, very good. Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, and they’ll tell you exactly when and how long, you know, the kids, exposure, all of that he will explain. But we will start with giving you a side effects sheet and then I’ll have J____ come in and just tell J____, our nurse, Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: about what to expect and how she’s going to do the prior authorization and then well we’ll kick you to the curb. Okay? Patient: Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: We’ll get out next one for I think it’s two months from now maybe for the shot. Family Member: Yeah. It will be the time for the Lupron.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we did tissue testing because one of the ways of resistance is if they had that P10 loss which your tissue did. And that’s why we put you on this uh medication that at least you’ve tolerated amazingly well. I mean you really haven’t had any side effects, haven’t felt any different, managed to keep up with everything you want to do. So that’s been remarkable. The PSA last couple of times as we discussed last time has been going up. Okay. One of my concerns is if it keeps going up but the scans don’t change, do we stay the same course? And honestly for how well you’re doing, that’s what I’m tempted to do. Okay. If however your bone scan shows me new areas or things growing then we are going to stop this treatment and go to something else. Patient: I see. Doctor: Now as we sort of discussed a little bit, the something else could either be going back and doing chemotherapy with Dr. K____ okay that’s a potential option. And, or if we want to give it one more try with doing a different kind of hormonal therapy, we have a new hormone therapy agent that we are testing here you know that’s been through multiple people who have had it and there’s been some promising results initially so I think that would be another option. Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But you know so those are probably the potential choices. The third possible choice and that would depend on your CAT scans had some lymph nodes though that were seen so there is a study with a combination of two different therapies. Okay? One is the Xofigo which is a radiation treatment that’s approved. You’ve probably heard of it I know. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Okay but you also had lymph nodes in the belly that were related to the prostate cancer. Patient: Oh. Family Member: No I didn’t know that. Okay. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have a number of clinical studies uh, that, uh, are in various per deviations of what we could do. Um. So, we || um, have a study of chemotherapy. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Plus vitamin C. That was data that suggest that vitamin C may reduce the side effects from the chemotherapy, may enhance its activity. We don’t know that. That’s a research question. And, so, um then, you are going to go on chemotherapy and are willing to participate, get randomized to get the vitamin C or a dummy infusion. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. That is cumbersome for someone like you. Uh, you’d have to come in at least twice a week to get the vitamin C. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The chemo is every three weeks, but the vitamin C is in high doses and it’s infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, uh, and, as of now, I still think even the placebo equaled yet a dummy infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so, you come in and maybe get tons of sugar. Um. And, we’re trying to sort out side effects of the Docetaxel, and then we can sort of compare it between the two groups --- is, do people have better PSA responses, longer PSA responses or there is no benefit to adding the vitamin C? Patient: Yeah. Okay.

Patient: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles) Family Member: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question – Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand. Doctor: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh. Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know?

Healthcare Professional: No. Family Member: February is Presidents’ Day? Healthcare Professional: Yeah we’re not – That will be the Monday the nineteenth. Family Member: Right, okay, this is a Tuesday, okay. Doctor: I think even before that we should - Patient: I’m available whenever you – I’ve already alerted - Healthcare Professional: Yes, okay. Doctor: So get in touch with ___ and/or myself. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And let me know that you’re coming actually the week after that. Like as soon as you feel you kinda know and then if we do go down the route of radiation therapy I can refer you to the radiation oncologist here to do that treatment. Patient: Okay, and now what would your role continue to be when I move to another physician? Doctor: Yes, I don’t deliver radiation therapy since I’m a medical oncologist.

Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving?

Patient: No. Doctor: Uh, the medicines that you take. You’re on – I thought you’re taking your, uh, apixaban or Eliquis? Five milligrams? Patient: Right. Doctor: You take that once a day, twice a day? Patient: Twice a day uh. Once in the morning and once at night. (Pause) Doctor: And then bupropion or Wellbutrin a hundred and fifty milligrams a day? Or twice a day? Patient: Twice, uh, I think they are seventy milligrams twice a day. Doctor: Okay – again, they’re a hundred and fifty or three hundreds? Patient: Oh, okay. Then they must be a hundred and fifties. Doctor: And so you take it once a day or twice a day? Patient: Twice a day. Patient: I try to get a thousand milligrams in. Doctor: Do you take that twice?

Patient: Now I get the impression he might do more than just the two that were were pressing right now. Doctor: I think that would be important for us because Patient: Yeah. Doctor: we may need to you know not treat them all and leave one so that you’re actually eligible- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -for the trial, which is a terrible thing to say. Patient: Well, I mean- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -at least we’re going to get them all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean - I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, you just need to know where he wants to put the

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m saying that that’s um you know I’ll do that twice just so… Family Member: Okay. Patient: You know I got an appointment with you later in June does that cancel? Doctor: No we’ll cancel that because we don’t need it. Yeah don’t worry about that. (Laughs) Patient: Well I was just wondering. Doctor: Yeah we’ll figure that out. Family Member: Never mind then. Doctor: Depending on the cryo if you decide to go with that and all of that and when Dr. C____ does it, then your next appointments will be changed Patient: Yep. Doctor: according to that. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Sound like a plan?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Essentially again with the shot and stuff, it didn’t change. Doctor: Exactly. No. You’re great. You had the last shot June sixth. You’re fine with that. So we’re going to extend it a week or two. Patient: Going to the bathroom. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. You’re eating fine. Patient: I’m eating fine. I’m eating good. Patient: I’m going to eat right now. Doctor: Oh. You’re taking her to lunch? Patient: Yeah. I’m taking her to lunch. Doctor: That’s nice. Where you guys going? Patient: Downtown somewhere. Doctor: Oh. Did you check out the, the, S___ S___? Do you guys ever go in there? Family Member: No. Doctor: It’s really good.

Patient: There’s the first one is – is whoops, one of them is from um March of fifteen to um November of fifteen and then the second one is January of sixteen to March of seventeen. Doctor: Okay. And I forgot, I think I asked you this before, do you have a nephrologist? Patient: No. I do not. Doctor: This is your primary care person checking it right? Patient: Yeah. But whoever was doing – ordering the vitals. Doctor: Yeah, gotcha. Patient: The vitals, the vitals, the uh what do they call it, comes in a comprehensive uh metabolic, metabolic panel. Doctor: Yeah, you were as high as one point seven five, May twenty-sixteen? Patient: No I think in fifteen I was even higher than that. Doctor: And then um (papers shuffling) Patient: I don’t know that your medication is the one that’s the problem. Doctor: It’s probably not.

Patient: Yeah. Hum, that, but I call R___ about, huh, that. Oh. I don’t know. That , it ran out. They sent it seven days too early, and there’s no refills. That’s what I’m saying about, starting seven days early, but I still need them, and I need Doctor: That kind of stuff I can help you with uh if you need a refill, um. Patient: Okay. When I take the ibuprofen, then I might only have to take one of the morphine. You know what I’m saying? More during the day, if the pain coming back just take the ibuprofen and I won’t need morphine. (Coughs) Doctor: So I have a known history, and your hepatitis C, they treated it. Right? Patient: No. It’s in, not, huh, you know how you, huh, you go get this medicine for it? They say I’m not in that category to get anything for it. Doctor: Okay. So your, your hepatitis C isn’t serious and hasn’t, huh, caused any-? Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. That may be the biggest, huh, roadblock. It says have a known history of hepatitis C infection. Huh, it is one of the things that would make it so that you can’t do the style, the study. I can still give you the chemo, huh, but it may be that you’re not eligible for the trial because of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Some of that we just have to check with the study team, huh, to see that this is up to date, huh, or not. I don’t have a paperclip. I’m going to check before you head out to see if I can get one for you. Huh, but again, we’ll have to see whether this one makes sense for you or not because of the hep C stuff. It doesn’t mean I can’t give you the chemo. It may be from a trial thing, you’re not allowed to do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we also, the other thing you might need a blood transfusion to become eligible, huh, so we’ll have to keep an eye on that one too, if we had to do that. Huh, so let’s go over your medicines. So you said that, huh, your ibuprofen was written on February nineteenth. You have no refills. Patient: Right.
